conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the normal force \( F_N \) between the latch \( D \) and the lock groove \( E \) when the system is in a self-locking state, we will analyze the forces acting on the latch \( D \) and use equilibrium conditions.

From the diagram in Figure B, the forces acting on the latch \( D \) are: Spring force (\( F_{\text{spring}} = kx \)), Normal force (\( F_N \)), Friction force (\( f \)), Components of forces along the inclined plane.
The maximum friction force is given by \( f = \mu F_N \).

premise: The forces acting on the latch \( D \) are: Spring force (\( F_{\text{spring}} = kx \)), Normal force (\( F_N \)), Friction force (\( f = \mu F_N \)).
conclusion: The spring force acts horizontally to the right, the normal force acts perpendicular to the inclined surface, and the friction force opposes the motion of the latch and acts parallel to the inclined surface.
Let the inclination angle of the latch be \( \theta = 30^\circ \).

The components of the spring force are: Along the inclined plane: \( F_{\text{spring, parallel}} = kx \cos\theta \), Perpendicular to the inclined plane: \( F_{\text{spring, perpendicular}} = kx \sin\theta \).
The components of the normal force are: Along the inclined plane: \( F_{N, parallel} = F_N \sin\theta \), Perpendicular to the inclined plane: \( F_{N, perpendicular} = F_N \cos\theta \).
Friction acts along the inclined plane, opposing the motion.
For the latch to be in a self-locking state, the latch must be in equilibrium. This means the net force along both the horizontal and vertical directions must be zero.

premise: Equilibrium condition along the inclined plane: Spring force component \( kx \cos\theta \), Friction force \( \mu F_N \), Normal force component \( F_N \sin\theta \).
Equilibrium condition perpendicular to the inclined plane: Spring force component \( kx \sin\theta \), Normal force component \( F_N \cos\theta \).
